page.title: 01Thurso, Caithness
page.content: Thurso, population 9500, is the most northerly town on the Scottish coast. Thurso comes from "Thors-a" meaning Thor's river, Thor being the Viking God of War.Thurso was the gateway to the southern part of the Norse kingdom Norse leaders gave their names to streets such as Thorfinn Terrace, Sigurd Road, St. Olaf Road, Sweyn Road Magnus Road and Thorkel Road. Thurso, once a fishing village, was built round the bay and the river. New estates have been built since 1955 to accommodate the new workforce at the Dounreay Atomic Power Station, ten miles west of the town. Rocky cliffs border the Victoria Walk which leads to the town's esplanade and beach where swimmers bathe safely. Anglers fish the river for salmon. Summer tourists use Thurso as a base to visit places of interest in Caithness.
